hints_html: Use the information about the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of P to calculate the n-th power Pn of P.
hints_raw: Use the information about the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of ''P'' to calculate the ''n''-th power ''P''<sup>''n''</sup> of ''P''.
question: B 03 (c)
sols_html:
We know that the probability vector after \(n\) steps is determined by multiplying the initial state by the matrix \(P\), \(n\)times.

We begin by expressing the initial probability vector in terms of the eigenvectors of \(P\). i.e:

\[\begin{aligned} c_{1}\left[\begin{array}{c} 1/4 \\ 2/3 \end{array}\right] + c_{2}\left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ -1 \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 0 \end{array}\right]\\ \left[ \begin{array}{cc} 1/4 & 1 \\ 2/3 & -1 \end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{c} c_{1} \\ c_{2} \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 0 \end{array}\right] \\ \left[ \begin{array}{cc} 1/4 & 1 \\ 11/12 & 0 \end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{c} c_{1} \\ c_{2} \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 1 \end{array}\right] \\ \left[ \begin{array}{cc} 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 \end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{c} c_{1} \\ c_{2} \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{c} 8/11 \\ 12/11 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

Thus \(c_{1} = 12/11\), \(c_{2} = 8/11\).

Now that we know the values of the constants, we will exploit the relationship

\[\begin{aligned} P\mathbf{v}_{k} = \lambda_{k}\mathbf{v}_{k} \quad \rightarrow \quad P^{n}\mathbf{v}_{k} = \lambda_{k}^{n}\mathbf{v}_{k},\end{aligned}\]

which holds for eigenvectors vk.

Using our answer from part b), we have the following

\[\begin{aligned} P^{n}\left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 0 \end{array}\right] &= P^{n}(c_{1}\mathbf{v}_{1} + c_{2}\mathbf{v}_{2})\\ &= c_{1}\lambda_{1}^{n}\mathbf{v}_{1} + c_{2}\lambda_{2}^{n}\mathbf{v}_{2} \\ &= \frac{12}{11}\left[\begin{array}{c} 1/4 \\ 2/3 \end{array}\right] + \frac{8}{11}\left(\frac{1}{12}\right)^{n}\left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ -1 \end{array}\right] \\ &= \frac{1}{11}\left[\begin{array}{c} 3 + 8\left(\frac{1}{12}\right)^{n} \\ 8 - 8\left(\frac{1}{12}\right)^{n} \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

Therefore, assuming that the walker starts in state 1, the probability that the walker is in state 1 after \(n\) steps is

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{11}\left( 3 + 8\left(\frac{1}{12}\right)^{n} \right)\end{aligned}\]

You can also solve this directly when you diagonalize P:

\[\begin{aligned} P = M D M^{-1}\end{aligned}\]

where M is the matrix with the eigenvectors of P as its columns, and D is a diagonal matrix with the corresponding eigenvalues on its diagonal. The catch is that then

\[\begin{aligned} P^n = MD^n M^{-1}\end{aligned}\]

and that powers of a diagonal matrix D are very easy to calculate.

So let’s do the work: Recall that and an eigenvector to the eigenvalue 1 is \(v = \left[\begin{array}{c} 1/4 \\ 2/3 \end{array}\right]\), and an eigenvector to the eigenvalue 1/12 is \(w = \left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ -1 \end{array}\right]\). Possible choices of M and D are therefore

\[\begin{aligned} M &= \left[\begin{array}{cc} 1/4 & 1 \\ 2/3 & -1 \end{array}\right] \quad \text{and} \quad D &= \left[\begin{array}{cc} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1/12 \end{array}\right] \\ \text{or} \\ M &= \left[\begin{array}{cc} 1 & 1/4 \\ -1 & 2/3 \end{array}\right] \quad \text{and} \quad D &= \left[\begin{array}{cc} 1/12 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{array}\right] \end{aligned}\]

Multiplying any column of M (but not of D) by a non-zero constant is also possible. We choose the former matrices M and D.

Next step is to find M-1, which is particularly easy for a 2x2 matrix since we use the formula

\[\begin{aligned} \left(\left[\begin{array}{cc} a & b \\ c & d \end{array}\right]\right)^{-1} = \frac1{ad-bc} \left[\begin{array}{cc} d & -b \\ -c & a \end{array}\right].\end{aligned}\]

Therefore, we obtain

\[\begin{aligned} P &= MDM^{-1} \\ \left[\begin{array}{cc} 1/3 & 1/4 \\ 2/3 & 3/4\end{array}\right] &= \left[\begin{array}{cc} 1/4 & 1 \\ 2/3 & -1 \end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{cc} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1/12 \end{array}\right] \frac{-12}{11} \left[\begin{array}{cc} -1 & -1 \\ -2/3 & 1/4 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

Therefore

\[\begin{aligned} P^n &= MD^nM^{-1} \\ &= \left[\begin{array}{cc} 1/4 & 1 \\ 2/3 & -1 \end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{cc} 1^n & 0 \\ 0 & (1/12)^n \end{array}\right] \frac{-12}{11} \left[\begin{array}{cc} -1 & -1 \\ -2/3 & 1/4 \end{array}\right] \\ \\ &= \frac{-12}{11} \left[\begin{array}{cc} -\frac14 - \frac23(\frac1{12})^n & -\frac14+\frac14(\frac1{12})^n \\ -\frac23+\frac23(\frac1{12})^n & -\frac23 - \frac14(\frac1{12})^n \end{array}\right] \\ \\ &= \frac1{11} \left[\begin{array}{cc} 3+ 8(\frac1{12})^n & 3-3(\frac1{12})^n \\ 8-8(\frac1{12})^n & 8+3(\frac1{12})^n \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

Hence, finally, we can conclude that

\[\begin{aligned} P^n \left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 0 \end{array}\right] &= \frac1{11} \left[\begin{array}{cc} 3+ 8(\frac1{12})^n & 3-3(\frac1{12})^n \\ 8-8(\frac1{12})^n & 8+3(\frac1{12})^n \end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 0 \end{array}\right] \\ &= \frac1{11} \left[\begin{array}{c} 3+ 8(\frac1{12})^n \\ 8-8(\frac1{12})^n \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

which means that the probability of being at stage 1 after n steps is

\[\begin{aligned} \frac1{11} \left(3+8\left(\frac1{12}\right)^n\right)\end{aligned}\]
sols_latex:
We know that the probability vector after $n$ steps is determined by
multiplying the initial state by the matrix $P$, $n$times.

We begin by expressing the initial probability vector in terms of the
eigenvectors of $P$. i.e:

\begin{align*}
c_{1}\left[\begin{array}{c} 1/4 \\ 2/3 \end{array}\right] + c_{2}\left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ -1 \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 0 \end{array}\right]\\ 
\left[ \begin{array}{cc} 1/4 & 1 \\ 2/3 & -1 \end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{c} c_{1} \\ c_{2} \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 0 \end{array}\right] \\
\left[ \begin{array}{cc} 1/4 & 1 \\ 11/12 & 0 \end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{c} c_{1} \\ c_{2} \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 1 \end{array}\right] \\
\left[ \begin{array}{cc} 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 \end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{c} c_{1} \\ c_{2} \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{c} 8/11 \\ 12/11 \end{array}\right]
\end{align*} Thus $c_{1} = 12/11$, $c_{2} = 8/11$.

Now that we know the values of the constants, we will exploit the
relationship

\begin{align*}
P\mathbf{v}_{k} = \lambda_{k}\mathbf{v}_{k} \quad \rightarrow \quad P^{n}\mathbf{v}_{k} = \lambda_{k}^{n}\mathbf{v}_{k},
\end{align*}

which holds for eigenvectors \textbf{v}\textsubscript{\emph{k}}.

Using our answer from part b), we have the following

\begin{align*}
P^{n}\left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 0 \end{array}\right] &= P^{n}(c_{1}\mathbf{v}_{1} + c_{2}\mathbf{v}_{2})\\  &= c_{1}\lambda_{1}^{n}\mathbf{v}_{1} + c_{2}\lambda_{2}^{n}\mathbf{v}_{2} \\
&= \frac{12}{11}\left[\begin{array}{c} 1/4 \\ 2/3 \end{array}\right] + \frac{8}{11}\left(\frac{1}{12}\right)^{n}\left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ -1 \end{array}\right] \\
&= \frac{1}{11}\left[\begin{array}{c} 3 + 8\left(\frac{1}{12}\right)^{n} \\ 8 - 8\left(\frac{1}{12}\right)^{n} \end{array}\right]
\end{align*}

Therefore, assuming that the walker starts in state 1, the probability
that the walker is in state 1 after $n$ steps is

\begin{align*}
\frac{1}{11}\left( 3 + 8\left(\frac{1}{12}\right)^{n} \right)
\end{align*}
sols_raw:
We know that the probability vector after <math>n</math> steps is determined by multiplying the initial state by the matrix <math>P</math>,  <math>n</math>times.

We begin by expressing the initial probability vector in terms of the eigenvectors of <math>P</math>. i.e:

:<math>
\begin{align}
c_{1}\left[\begin{array}{c} 1/4 \\ 2/3 \end{array}\right] + c_{2}\left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ -1 \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 0 \end{array}\right]\\ 
\left[ \begin{array}{cc} 1/4 & 1 \\ 2/3 & -1 \end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{c} c_{1} \\ c_{2} \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 0 \end{array}\right] \\
\left[ \begin{array}{cc} 1/4 & 1 \\ 11/12 & 0 \end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{c} c_{1} \\ c_{2} \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 1 \end{array}\right] \\
\left[ \begin{array}{cc} 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 \end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{c} c_{1} \\ c_{2} \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{c} 8/11 \\ 12/11 \end{array}\right]
\end{align}
</math>
Thus <math>c_{1} = 12/11</math>, <math>c_{2} = 8/11</math>.

Now that we know the values of the constants, we will exploit the relationship

:<math>
P\mathbf{v}_{k} = \lambda_{k}\mathbf{v}_{k} \quad \rightarrow \quad P^{n}\mathbf{v}_{k} = \lambda_{k}^{n}\mathbf{v}_{k},
</math>

which holds for eigenvectors '''v'''<sub>''k''</sub>.

Using our answer from part b), we have the following

:<math>
\begin{align}
P^{n}\left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 0 \end{array}\right] &= P^{n}(c_{1}\mathbf{v}_{1} + c_{2}\mathbf{v}_{2})\\  &= c_{1}\lambda_{1}^{n}\mathbf{v}_{1} + c_{2}\lambda_{2}^{n}\mathbf{v}_{2} \\
&= \frac{12}{11}\left[\begin{array}{c} 1/4 \\ 2/3 \end{array}\right] + \frac{8}{11}\left(\frac{1}{12}\right)^{n}\left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ -1 \end{array}\right] \\
&= \frac{1}{11}\left[\begin{array}{c} 3 + 8\left(\frac{1}{12}\right)^{n} \\ 8 - 8\left(\frac{1}{12}\right)^{n} \end{array}\right]
\end{align}
</math>

Therefore, assuming that the walker starts in state 1, the probability that the walker is in state 1 after <math>n</math> steps is 

:<math>
\frac{1}{11}\left( 3 + 8\left(\frac{1}{12}\right)^{n} \right)
</math>
You can also solve this directly when you diagonalize ''P'':

:<math> P = M D M^{-1} </math>

where ''M'' is the matrix with the eigenvectors of ''P'' as its columns, and ''D'' is a diagonal matrix with the corresponding eigenvalues on its diagonal. The catch is that then

:<math> P^n = MD^n M^{-1} </math>

and that powers of a diagonal matrix ''D'' are very easy to calculate.

So let's do the work: Recall that and an eigenvector to the eigenvalue '''1''' is <math> v = \left[\begin{array}{c} 1/4 \\ 2/3 \end{array}\right] </math>, and an eigenvector to the eigenvalue '''1/12''' is  <math> w = \left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ -1 \end{array}\right] </math>. Possible choices of ''M'' and ''D'' are therefore

:<math> \begin{align}
M &= \left[\begin{array}{cc} 1/4 & 1 \\ 2/3 & -1 \end{array}\right] \quad \text{and} \quad D &= \left[\begin{array}{cc} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1/12 \end{array}\right] \\
\text{or} \\
M &= \left[\begin{array}{cc} 1 & 1/4 \\ -1 & 2/3 \end{array}\right] \quad \text{and} \quad D &= \left[\begin{array}{cc} 1/12 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{array}\right] \\
\end{align} </math>

Multiplying any column of ''M'' (but not of ''D'') by a non-zero constant is also possible. We choose the former matrices ''M'' and ''D''.

Next step is to find ''M''<sup>''-1''</sup>, which is particularly easy for a ''2''x''2'' matrix since we use the formula

:<math>
\left(\left[\begin{array}{cc} a & b \\ c & d \end{array}\right]\right)^{-1} = \frac1{ad-bc} \left[\begin{array}{cc} d & -b \\ -c & a \end{array}\right].
</math>

Therefore, we obtain

:<math> \begin{align}
P &= MDM^{-1} \\
\left[\begin{array}{cc} 1/3 & 1/4 \\ 2/3 & 3/4\end{array}\right] &= \left[\begin{array}{cc} 1/4 & 1 \\ 2/3 & -1 \end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{cc} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1/12 \end{array}\right] \frac{-12}{11} \left[\begin{array}{cc} -1 & -1 \\ -2/3 & 1/4 \end{array}\right]
\end{align}
</math>

Therefore

:<math> \begin{align}
P^n &= MD^nM^{-1} \\
&= \left[\begin{array}{cc} 1/4 & 1 \\ 2/3 & -1 \end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{cc} 1^n & 0 \\ 0 & (1/12)^n \end{array}\right] \frac{-12}{11} \left[\begin{array}{cc} -1 & -1 \\ -2/3 & 1/4 \end{array}\right] \\ \\
&= \frac{-12}{11} \left[\begin{array}{cc} -\frac14 - \frac23(\frac1{12})^n & -\frac14+\frac14(\frac1{12})^n \\ -\frac23+\frac23(\frac1{12})^n & -\frac23 - \frac14(\frac1{12})^n \end{array}\right] \\ \\
&= \frac1{11} \left[\begin{array}{cc} 3+ 8(\frac1{12})^n & 3-3(\frac1{12})^n \\ 8-8(\frac1{12})^n & 8+3(\frac1{12})^n \end{array}\right]
\end{align}
</math>

Hence, finally, we can conclude that

:<math> \begin{align}
P^n \left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 0 \end{array}\right] &= \frac1{11} \left[\begin{array}{cc} 3+ 8(\frac1{12})^n & 3-3(\frac1{12})^n \\ 8-8(\frac1{12})^n & 8+3(\frac1{12})^n \end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 0 \end{array}\right] \\
&= \frac1{11} \left[\begin{array}{c} 3+ 8(\frac1{12})^n \\ 8-8(\frac1{12})^n \end{array}\right]
\end{align}
</math>

which means that the probability of being at stage ''1'' after ''n'' steps is

:<math> \frac1{11} \left(3+8\left(\frac1{12}\right)^n\right) </math>
statement_html:
A random walk problem with two states has a transition matrix

\[\begin{aligned} P = \left[\begin{array}{cc} 1/3 & 1/4 \\ 2/3 & 3/4\end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

c) Assume that the walker starts in state 1. Give an explicit formula that only depends on \(n\) for the probability it is in state 1 after \(n\) time steps.
statement_latex:
A random walk problem with two states has a transition matrix

\begin{align*}
P = \left[\begin{array}{cc} 1/3 & 1/4 \\ 2/3 & 3/4\end{array}\right]
\end{align*}

c) Assume that the walker starts in state 1. Give an explicit formula
that only depends on $n$ for the probability it is in state 1 after $n$
time steps.
statement_raw:
A random walk problem with two states has a transition matrix

:<math>
P = \left[\begin{array}{cc} 1/3 & 1/4 \\ 2/3 & 3/4\end{array}\right]
</math>

c) Assume that the walker starts in state 1. Give an explicit formula that only
depends on <math>n</math> for the probability it is in state 1 after <math>n</math> time steps.
